reviewText: This is by far one of the best Christian films that I have seen, and it presents important issues for consideration for both non-believers and believers in Jesus.For non-Christians, the effect of our society's moral relativism on peoples' lives and interactions with others is shown. People get hurt and hurt others all the time because everybody is too busy doing what "works for ME." Most people do try to be good people, but they think that this means avoiding only the 'big' sins like murder, assault, rape, etc.; they think nothing of lying, stealing, sexual immorality and a slew of other, 'little' sins. This film contains the reminder that no one can be good apart from Christ; as the Bible states, if we do things apart from God, then all our good works are as "filthy rags" to Him. The good news, which this film also clearly presents, is that forgiveness and salvation are available through Jesus, and that He has prepared good works for us to do in order that we can be a blessing to others (not to try to earn our way into heaven, which we can never do).However, this is not just a film for the non-believer; it also forces Christians to look at how we are living our lives. I must admit that I got a bit uncomfortable during the scenes in which the characters discuss a movie that their church group has just seen. We have to walk a fine line between not isolating ourselves from the world and yet not succumbing to its temptations either. The movie-discussion scene shows how easily we sometimes give in to the world rather than maintaining our standards and providing an example for non-believers. It also provides good reminders that we should not begin to take our faith for granted and simply 'go through the motions' of worship and church activities.Although the film has many important messages, it is also a good piece of entertainment. As I was watching it, I began to think of it (quite obviously) as a Christian version of H.G. Wells's "The Time Machine." Fortunately, because of it's focus on Jesus, this film has a more positive outlook than Wells's novel (and the films based on it) had. Rich Christiano, his cast, and his crew are to be commended for this excellent movie.
summary: A cut above most Christian movies and it has something for all people

reviewText: Although the premise is on time travel, the story is credible in the "what-if" scenario.  The story line is on a professor of bible studies at Grace Seminary in 1890.  He is attempting to get one of his works published and needs the coveted endorsement of the seminary where he teaches.  He has all board memebers' approval except one.  Here, the story gets better.  He has some extended conversations with the professor who refuses to give his endorsement and both characters are at odds with one another.  Eventually, the professor (David Morin) must decide for himself why his work is not quite "up to par" with the antagonist professor Anderson (Gavin McLeod).  To prove his point, professor Anderson sends the irritated Carlisle into the future to test his "works" and make the decision for himself.The acting in the movie are good to excellent.  Most of the stars in the movie are comfortable in their roles, especially Jennifer O'Neil, who gives a 4 minute take on the movie industry, in which she once worked in, in her role of Christian librarian (since she is Christian in real life, I suspect she was also revealing her Christian background in her role).  Her part was small for such a star of her caliber.  Hal Linden, Richard Reihle, Paul Rodriguez and Gavin McLeod give good performances.There were some "holes" that should have been filled in a longer version of the film, but trying to keep it at an hour and half, the film makes the story a little "less filling" than it should be.  The story could have been longer and certainly more entertaining with its special effects.  But, ultimately, the story has a very strong message and that is that Jesus Christ is THE only answer.  This may offend some people but this is, after all, a Christian movie that is geared for those who are either teetering on their faith or those who need to hear the "truth."This Christian film is Hollywood quality (albeit, no where near the production levels of some of the major multi-million dollar films), and the film making of Rich Christiano is excellent.  I highly recomment the film, if only to have a "readjustment" of your personal views or to have some of your family and friends view it to evangelize.  Overall, the film is of high quality and strong Christian-based values and morals.

reviewText: So how would YOU feel meeting a throw-forward from the 1890's? Or, how would you feel if you were transported forward 100 years into the future...Time Changer, an amazing new film directed by Christian producer Rich Christiano, is finally on DVD and home video. This movie is a surprisingly well produced and well done film by Five & Two pictures, and boasts some surprisingly big actors featured in the film.PLOT: Dr. Russell Carlisle (D. David Morin), a professor at Grace Bible Seminary, has just completed a new book entitled The Changing Times. He hopes to secure approval and endorsement from the board of directors at the Seminary. However, one board member, Dr. Norris Anderson (Gavin McLeod, of "Mary Tyler Moore" and "Love Boat" fame) disapproves of the work, on grounds of the book's premise that the teachings of Christ can be taught apart from the NAME of Christ. This disturbs Dr. Carlisle, and he resolves to fight the Unanimous rule the Seminary holds for any book endorsement. His efforts are rejected by the Dean of the college, played by Hal Linden (Of "Barney Miller" fame). Carlisle avoids Dr. Anderson for a while, despite Anderson's pleas for him to come to his home and discuss the matter. At last, Russell relents and goes to Norris's house, where Norris shows Russell his convenient time machine, located in his barn. (Those things DO come in handy from time to time) Norris rockets Russell more than a hundred years into the future to see the moral deprivation of the age. Russell is blown away by the absence of belief in Jesus in the world, let alone the culture shock of the 21st century. He realizes the terrible mistake he made in thinking God's moral law can be laid down without the authority of God's name behind it, when trying to law down this law and getting only "Says who?" in response.GOOD: Obviously, the film is a Christian film, and contains very, very little of what any movie goer might consider bad, unless the wholesome religious themes offend you. The quality of the film underscores the excellent production and effort that went into this movie. The fact that such big names as Gavin McLeod, Jennifer O'Neill and Hal Linden are featured in this film just goes to show you; Some actors can be Christians after all. The music and visual effects are very well done for the mood, especially when you consider that both areas were headed up by professional yet youthful gentlemen.BAD: As much as it pains me to say it, there are several moments where it appears that D. David Morin needs much more acting experience. It is unclear to me whether or not the strange and stoic action is an attempt to display the common character and attitude of the era, but it only serves to appear to me like any other bad actor I've seen. As far as any other objectionable material, there is none. No kid will be frightened by the brief special teleportation effects, I'm sure.THOUGHTS: This movie offers some important insight into the culture of today. Through gradual desensitization, things like nearly nude models in the mall don't bother us any more, or at least most of us. We attend movies that wouldn't be the choice of our Savior, if He were in the theater today. While sending an important message to born-again believers, it also sends the all-important message to non-believers, and doing it in an entertaining way. Purely from a quality standpoint, there are included theatrical trailers, as well as a great 57-minute behind-the-scenes feature.I must give this movie 7  out of ten stars.

reviewText: As an evangelical Christian, I believe Time Changers had so much potential. The concept of the film reminded of the late '70's film "Time After Time" in which both Jack the Ripper and HG Wells are both transported to the present. HG Wells, a secular humanist, is appalled at the violence, sex, and morals of modern day. Jack the Ripper, in contrast, loves the present day, saying in effect, "I belong here." While not a Christian film by any stretch, does a much better job contrasting the past to the present.D. David Morin (playing the part of the main character) was simply painful to watch; what was director Rich Christiano thinking casting him for the role? The other actors were fine for this kind of film, which otherwise had a "made for TV" feel to it.More importantly, the sins of society of the 1890's (child labor, institutionalized racism, graft, corruption, 3rd world conditions for American workers) were completely ignored ... and the sins of the present seemed focused solely on sex, divorce, and taking God's name in vain. Is God concerned with righteousness? You bet, but He's also concerned with justice. For a taste of what life was really like 116 years ago, read any of the speeches of William Jennings Bryan (3 time Democratic candidate for President), or Republican President Theodore Roosevelt.Rather than the film causing those who are not Christians to walk away with something significant to ponder and think about, it ended up sermonizing and preaching to the choir.I've read all the reviews and my apologies to non-Christians who were led to believe this was a "science fiction" film. It should have been listed as a "relgious" or "Christian" film. It had a lot of potential ... kinda sad. To paraphrase Larry Norman "why does the devil have all the good movies?"Actually, he doesn't. "To End All Wars" (rated R for extreme wartime violence) stars Robert Carlye and Kiefer Sutherland is an excellent film - and is based on a true story of the lives of Christians and non-Christians in a Japanese POW camp in WWII. I'd normally say it's too graphic for most church crowds (of which I'm part of) but look at the success of Mel Gibson's "The Passion of the Christ."David, in Los Angeles

reviewText: Let me get right of the bat that I am not the movie's intended audience.  I have my own values and I don't think anyone should force me to change them.  Matter of fact, I saw this out of a recommendation by someone because I was looking for 'questionable' films.  "Time Changer" is definitely questionable, but I'm watching this film by its own merits, and to be fair, I was pleasantly entertained with it...for the wrong reasons.D. David Morin plays Russell, a bible scholar from the year 1890 who gave a transcript to his other scholars about using the teachings of Jesus without using his name.  He was then rebuked by Dr. Norris, played by Gavin MacLeod, saying that without enforcing the name Jesus in the teachings, the community will be lost in the fields.  The reverend doctor privately proved to Russell by showing a time machine, which Russell reluctantly gawked but decided to join in, sending him into our present to discover what HE thinks is the last days of humanity.  Throughout this bizarre turn of events which question if this religion even accept such a method as a time machine, all I can think about was "what's wrong with teaching good Christian values without mentioning Jesus?  Isn't it important to teach the faith-goers about how to be a decent person to the world?"Russell is a peculiar character.  In the future (our present time), he goes around preaching the ways of The Lord, eavesdropping and interrupting other people's business, and outspokenly critical about certain aspects of contemporary society.  I find him to be rude, condescending, incapable of keeping things to himself...and hilarious. D. David Morin does a wonderful job at expressing confusion during the time travel experience, he had a doe-eyed face that stayed the same for most of the film, especially when's he facing what I would jokingly call obstacles.  The character was chasing a girl who stole a hot dog and he ran like he's squatting the whole way, his glare of disgust over women's 'sinful' apparels, the way he abrasively barged out of the theater and complained to the workers because a movie character used God's name in vain, the actor really phoned it in.  I wasn't sure if those goofy moments were intentional, but considering how passionate the director was in the Special Message feature, the movie was probably taken very seriously, which made the film even more funny.I would like to think the whole lesson of the film was to never forgot who taught the values that are necessary to live a good life, but since the real lesson was 'if you fear people into being good by saying Jesus judges them', then it becomes bureaucracy at work; actually, the ending is quite disturbing if Russell manages to alter time to his own accord.  "Time Changer" is certifiably church-friendly: it's safe, conventional, like the whole movie's made of marshmallows; even the antagonists in the film weren't remotely intimidating, all they did was follow the main lead and threaten to use force on him (like the movie would allow them such an action).  Despite the rather obnoxious message and silly premise as an excuse to deliver said message, I'm aware of what kind of film this is.  I wouldn't put their purpose against them, and at least I was somewhat enjoying it.

reviewText: Writing a review that says "I loved it" or "I hated it" is easy.  I'd be done by now if that's all there was to say.  But I'm assuming people read reviews to get a little more depth than just thumbs up or thumbs down.  And since this film had a bit of both, so will my review.First, the message of the film:  Outstanding.Times have changed, but not for the better.  Christians long for a simpler era not because we are nave, but because we instinctively understand that as The Day approaches, evil waxes worse and worse.  How bad is it?  By juxtaposing 1890 against 2007 as this film does, we begin to get a clue.  That proverbial frog in the pot has reached a full boil and we've barely noticed.Next, the inventiveness of the story.  Time travel is always an appealing topic because what one of us hasn't wondered or wished it could really happen?  There was a slight Jules Verne feel to the whole thing.  My son thought it looked like the computer game "Myst" and I had to agree.Third, the filmmakers didn't pull any punches here.  There was no attempt to water down the message to make it palatable.  We were asked to eat our veggies here a la natural, not slathered with creme sauce and butter.  I admired that.However, for its good points, there were at least an equal number of areas where I felt this film needed some major improvements.First, the science was, uh, hokey.  A 30-minute consult with a real physicist or post-grad student would have been time well-spent in terms of getting some more authentic terminology and ideas.  Remember, Einstein's work was barely 20 years away in the 1890s and he was building on some of the ideas of others - ideas that were around in the 1890s.  Some of that time/space/gravity/matter/energy continuum could have come through a little more credibly than just a few mumbled words about sunlight and singularities.  People will willingly suspend disbelief at the movies.  But you shouldn't make it quite so hard for them to do so.  Christopher Reeve's mind-over-matter time travel in the movie "Somewhere in Time" was frankly more believable, and dealt with a similar transition of crossing a century - but he went the other direction.  Something like that "mental bending of time" might actually have worked better here.Second, the production quality.  It was OK, but lacking attention to detail that makes the real difference between mediocre and outstanding.  The alleys were too clean, the bad elements of the city too sanitized, and the degree to which society had sunk relied too much on contrived scenes and dialog rather than just reality.Which brings me to the third point: the writing.  Just making Dr. Carlisle a silent observer through the whole movie rather than always having to verbalize what he was seeing would have been more powerful.  It's too bad because the writer had a fantastic story to tell.  He just let words get in the way too often.  Frankly, it insults the intelligence of the viewer when everything has to be spelled out verbally like a series of billboards along the freeway.Here's what I mean:  Some of the older readers of this review might remember a public service commercial that ran on TV about 25 years ago.  An Indian paddles up a metropolitan river in his canoe, dressed in his traditional buckskin clothing with a long black braid.  From the context it is clear that he is in some kind of time warp.  He surveys the land and instead of seeing the pristine beauty that he recalls, he sees smokestacks belching pollution, water covered with oily film, garbage everywhere, and industrial sprawl.  He never says a word through the whole thing.  He just paddles and turns to the camera at the end of the 30 second spot where we see a single, large tear running down his cheek.Less is more.No words were necessary to convey that message.  And 25 years later, I still remember it.That's what this film was missing in my opinion.  It tried to tell with words what wouldn't have been necessary had the story been better written to let our main character simply observe and convey with his body language what he was experiencing rather than having to verbally explain everything.  All that pent up realization could have been brought out powerfully during his mini-sermon at the end, rather than at each step of the journey.  The filmmaker here tried to do double duty as a screenwriter.  I think it would have worked better to get a real screenwriter to adapt the story and to know when silence would have spoken louder than words.  The problem wasn't in the fundamental story idea.  It was simply in the execution.Third, I really had a hard time with the believability of the main character here.  I understand that the turn-of-the-twentieth-century man or woman was going to be far more prim and proper in their use of language than we modern schleps.  But there was just something here that didn't ring authentic for me.  Gavin MacLeod's character, yes.  D. David Morin's character -- no.  The speech and the cadence just didn't sound natural.  In fact, before I realized that Dr. Carlisle was the main character, I thought that perhaps this was a bit part in the movie being played by someone who had never done much acting before  -- kind of like Frank Peretti taking small roles in some of the movies where he's been the screenwriter.Did I like the film?  Yes.  It made me think and reflect.  The message was valid and much-needed.  But it wasn't told as masterfully as it could have been, and this just isn't the kind of movie that is going to see much screen time outside church movie nights and folks who buy movies at the Christian bookstore.  If that's the audience the filmmaker was aiming for, then OK.  But if this film was meant to be some kind of message to non-believers, that just isn't likely to happen.It's too bad a movie like this couldn't have been told with the same skill and production quality that Mel Gibson was able to deliver in The Passion.  This message was just as important, as it told us not just what a culture in decline looks like, but why it happened.  Unfortunately, what came across here was at about the level I'd expect from a community theatre production.  Good, but just not quite ready for the major leagues.

reviewText: To be a "Christian film," TIME CHANGER has a very professional look, an excellent supporting cast, and some scenes that rise above its intended market.I enjoyed seeing Hal Linden, Gavin McLeod, Jennifer O'Neill (still absolutely beautiful), and Paul Rodriguez (who was also excellent in TORTILLA SOUP), but the lead actor comes off as stiff and inexperienced.  He reads lines like "Why does he cause me pain?" without showing any expression at all.Some scenes play like sermons where more human interaction could've made them more effective.  In the final scene between the lead character and Eddie (Rodriquez's character), it might have played deeper if Carlisle allowed more of his humility to show.  Defeated by his own pompous ambitions in the past, he could hint at his desperation to get the word out to just one person, even if it's the guy who manages an inner-city laundrymat.More tension could've been explored if the two guys investigating Carlisle had happened on a photo of him in their research (their final scene is a hoot though).I'm not sure if the filmmakers wanted to go there, but some genuinely funny scenes of Carlisle experiencing modern culture (rap music, teen fashions, MTV) could've been added.  I'm not sure if I was supposed to laugh, but I did find some amusement at Carlisle freaking out at the movie theatre and jumping in front of a TV to keep a child from seeing a couple kissing on TV.  Wouldn't it have been funny to see him yelling at the couple on the TV, thinking they were in a window?"Now, come out of there and control yourselves!"Maybe they just wanted to keep their Christian audience instead of possibly offending them.  The scene where Jennifer O'Neill explains how her character (or the filmmakers, for that matter) believe that films have become decadent illustrates their dilemma, perhaps.I'm not suggesting that these filmmakers "muddy" things up more to please a secular audience, but I am hoping for spiritual films in the future that challenges both Christian and secular audiences.  A challenge to the secular viewer to consider the message and a challenge to Christian filmmakers to present flawed, struggling believers who can relate to a lost and dying world.Either way, this is a big leap from the clunky religious movies I've seen over the years and I'll be looking for the next production from this company.

reviewText: I am really amazed by the reviews of this movie. People seem either to love it or hate it, based on whether or not they agree with the theology. But in all the discussion about theology, the movie itself seems to have gotten lost. What, really, is Rich Christiano, the director, trying to say, and how well does he say it?Just to add my two cents, briefly, to the theological discussion, from a Reformed theological viewpoint, Rich is right on in his premise: you cannot separate Jesus Christ from his teachings. It won't work. Either Jesus is Lord over every part of our lives, including our morality, or He's not Lord over any of it. But is film really the right forum, the right medium, in which to discuss such an issue? Isn't the purpose of film to tell a story?The story in Time Changer is about a 19th century seminary professor named Russell Carlisle, played by D. David Morin, who has written a thesis in which he tries to prove that you CAN separate Jesus from His teachings and still end up with a morally sound society. Another professor named Norris Anderson, played by Gavin MacLeod, is deeply disturbed by this, and sets out to disprove Carlisle's theory by sending him to the future in a time machine invented by his father. In doing this, he hopes to show Carlisle the morally corrupting effect his book will have on society, and thereby convince him to change it.Now, in theory, Rich Christiano has a good idea. But, in practice, it doesn't work. Why? Because storytelling is about character, plot, crisis, climax and resolution - not about proving a thesis. Rich's main character, Professor Carlisle, is a dislikable, inflexible, self-focused person who starts out relatively one-dimensional and remains so throughout the film. He lives in a world that is pretty much one-dimensional as well, filled with other one-dimensional people. It is interesting that Rich chose not to use any slang or other idioms that would have given color and dimensionality to his characters, when the 19th century was full of them, as indicated by the writings of Mark Twain and others. Instead, his language is stiff and formal, his characters are colorless, and there is very little relationally between them, even with Carlisle and his wife. Who are these people and why should we care about them? We never find out.Then, off Professor Carlisle goes into an equally one-dimensional, 20th century world, where people are ignorant of spiritual matters, all churches are worldly, and morality is a thing of the past. There, Carlisle interacts with the ignorant people and worldly church members, and is shocked by the lack of morality. But he never really gets involved with these people - not really. He soon realizes that Professor Anderson was right, and off he goes back to the 19th century to change his book and, thereby, change history.All well and good; but, do I care? I want to. But Rich Christiano has created a film in which it is very difficult to care, about any one or any thing - except his thesis. We cannot care about his one-dimensional professor or his one-dimensional world - they're not real. In his quest to prove his point, Rich has failed to engage us in his characters or to move us to care about what happens to them, and that is the biggest part of good storytelling.There are Christian films that do have wonderful stories and characters that have been fleshed out: Ben-Hur and Chariots of Fire are two outstanding examples. Those movies are worthy of five stars. An example of a Christian film in the same league as Time Changer, but more successful because of story and character development, is Joshua. Even though Time Changer is a good production with a noble goal, it fails to be a significant film because it forgets the most fundamental purpose of filmmaking: to tell a good story.Waitsel Smith
